section.heading: Argument of Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 413, North Carolina et al., petitioner versus Clifton A. Pearce.
Mr. Vanore.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

I am Andrew A. Vanore Jr., I'm a member of the staff for the Attorney General of North Carolina and I represent the petitioners, the State of North Carolina and Warden R.L. Turner in this particular case.

The single issue involved in this particular case is upon retrial for the same offense which has been set aside on appeal or post-conviction proceeding due to a constitutional defect in the first trial, may the second trial court impose a harsher punishment upon the defendant.

The facts briefly stated are Clifton A. Pearce, the respondent in this particular case, was initially tried at the May 1961 term of the Superior Court of Durham County, North Carolina on the capital charge of rape.
Upon arraignment, the prosecuting attorney or the solicitor announced that he would not seek a verdict in excess of assault with intent to commit rape.
The jury found the defendant guilty of assault with intent to commit rape and the judge imposed a sentence of 12 to 15 years upon the defendant.
The defendant started serving the sentence on May 25, 1961.
In 1965, the defendant filed a petition under the Post-Conviction Relief Act questioning the admissibility of a confession introduced against him in the first trial.

Relief was denied by the Superior Court of Durham County on May 10, 1965 and certiorari was accepted by the Supreme Court of North Carolina which reversed the case and awarded the defendant a new trial.
The defendant was released from custody upon the first sentence imposed upon him on February 2, 1966.
At that particular time, he had served four years, eight months and six days flat time and six years, seven months and 16 days flat and gain time.
The gain time being computed upon 150 days granted to the defendant for each year of service on the sentence.
The defendant was tried the second time at the June 6, 1966 term of the Superior Court of Durham County upon an indictment charging assault with intent to commit rape.

The jury found him guilty of assault with intent to commit rape and the presiding judge who specifically stated in his judgment that he was taking into consideration the fact that the defendant had served six years, seven months and 16 days flat and gain time was going to impose only a sentence of eight years upon the defendant.

The judge stated in his judgment that it was his intention to impose the maximum sentence allowed by statute for the offense which is 15 years however, because of the gain time and so forth he reduced it to eight years.
In March 19 --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Let's -- that -- there's a factor in this case that bothers me, if the sentence said the first time around on the first conviction was -- what was it, 12 to 15 years?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Ten to 12, something like that and second time around there was eight years, right?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, do I understand that it's the rule in North Carolina that you do give prisoners on their second conviction credit for time served?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
That is the rule as --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's the rule of law?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is rule announced by the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Does that include gain time?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That includes gain time, yes sir.
All credits served --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that the --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: -- upon the board, its sentence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes, so when this fellow was given eight-year sentence in the second trial if he had served the whole eight-year without any reference to additional gain time, he would've had to serve another one year and five months?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
The trial judge in taking into consideration the gain and flat time that the defendant it served, reduced it or deducted it from the maximum sentence allowed under statute, 15 years.
He did not reduce it from the minimum sentence that was imposed upon the defendant at the first trial that means 12 years.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You mean the sentence here was not eight years but 15 years?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: The sentence was eight years.
However, the judge said, it is my intention to give you a sentence of 15 years.

However, since you have served this particular flat and gain time upon the first sentence which was less than seven years, since you have served that time, I am going to deduct that time from the maximum of 15 years and impose an eight-year sentence upon you.
The --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So, he got eight years?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: He did in fact get eight years.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, if he had been given credit for the time served under the first sentence including plus gain time, he would've had only as I said before, you had only another -- what was it, year and five months served?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, assuming that the second trial judge would be prohibited from increasing his sentence upon the second trial.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, he would be, wouldn't he?
No, no, no, --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I think --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- I don't mean that.
I don't mean he wouldn't be.
No, I don't mean that he would be but I mean to say it already passed a sentence and the sentence was eight years, is that right?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Not 15 years but eight years?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, does the North Carolina law rule that you've just recited with respect to giving him credit the time served plus gain time applied to that eight-year sentence?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: It applies to the eight-year sentence, yes but I -- perhaps I'm not making myself clear Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I've struggled with this on the basis of the briefs and I'm still bewildered because if I -- just looking at this thing literally this follows to you to be sprung about now.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think there's any question about it.
Because of the eight-year sentence, he is going to have to serve some additional time other than he would've been required to serve under the first sentence.

But the reasoning of the trial judge is that he could have in fact imposed a 15-year sentence and if you give him all credit for time served under the 15-year sentence which he is required to do by a decision of the Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: -- then he still in fact has left to serve seven years.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I know but my problem here is this in truth and in fact a case -- does this case really present a situation in which the second sentence was greater than the first sentence.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: It does if you compute the time that he would have to serve in -- on the end of terminate sentence, the 12 to 15 years if you compute it from the lesser of the two sentences imposed from the 12-year sentence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: 12-year sentence?
Now, when would he be entitled to get out --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: He would be entitled --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- including maximum gain time which is fuller -- seems steadily govern?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: He would've been entitled to get out after having served eight years, five months and 22 days of actual time on the first sentence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright.
Now, that's --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Now there's a statute --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- bound to be less, that's bound to be less on the time he's got to serve under his second sentence?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
If we were to assume that he would be given credit under both of these sentences, the defendant would have to serve an additional sentence of one year, 10 months and 10 days because of the new trial.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Not because of -- well, you -- I -- this is much to elaborate.

I computed this yesterday on the basis of the briefs and I have very serious question in my mind as to whether we are in truth and in fact here faced with a situation in which the man would serve longer under the second sentence than to the second conviction and under the first conviction and --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, of course the District Court thought so and the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: District Court thought so

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: -- Fourth Circuit of Appeals thought so.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- but apparently the District Court had an idea that what had happen here was a 15-year sentence but it wasn't, it was an eight-year sentence on the second conviction.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: The District Court who saw the opinion based on the Fourth Circuit Court's opinion in Patton that the flat and gain time served under the original sentence would have to be deducted from the minimum of an indeterminate sentence and since it was not deducted from the 12 years but rather from the 15 years that was the infirmity that the District Court found in this particular sentence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Vanore, is this man been out on bail at all?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, he is out on bail now, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When did he get out on bail?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Approximately, six months ago.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, then except for that six months, he's been out on bail but for this new trial he'd be out for good.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: No, I believe that he would still have to serve approximately a year-and-a-half of the second sentence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He had seven-years from today?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, not computing the time that he's been out on bail, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yeah.
So, he would just about be out now?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And solely because he made a mistake of going to the Court and solely because the mistake the Court gave in giving him a new trial, he's got to serve more time, isn't that it?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, no.
I don't quite agree with you Justice Marshall.
I think that here, we have two points that we must consider.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What I mean -- speaking for the man, I imagine a very great difficulty in seeing anything other than fact he's got to serve more time solely because he was given a new trial.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm sure he feels that way, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Doesn't he have a little reason to feel that way?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I do not think so based on the principle of law that I think the case brings up before this Court whether or not the Patton rule which prohibits an increase sentence or which prohibits the state from giving the man a sentence over and above the sentence that was given at the first trial.

I think that the -- that question is a very basis of our system of jurisprudence and that it assumes that the trial judge, the second trial judge is going to punish this man for exercising a constitutional right of appeal.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Vanore, let me ask you this question.
Let me take you to a situation.

Now, suppose the judge of this case, in the second trial, have said that I'll give you the same sentence you were given in the first trial, subject of course to the law of the state that you're entitled to credit for the time you would serve plus the -- with the sentence you receive.
That's one situation.

Judge would assume, what we currently have here when the judge said that, I (Inaudible) figure out myself but the credit you were entitled to under your first sentence and what the time he served and I have no authority to give you a sentence of eight years this time.
Now, I wonder which of those two situations that the man have to serve for his sentence.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: He would have to serve the same amount of time under both situations.
Perhaps I misunderstood your question then.
Oh, he would have to serve more time under the second situation, I beg your pardon.
Excuse me, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, just the question about the (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: So long as it comes within the statutory maximum allowed for by the statute, yes.
I think that is the question whether or not a judge can give more time on the second trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's what I want (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, do you have the (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does North Carolina effectuate the statute which requires credit?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: By -- the judge takes in -- the second sentencing judge takes into consideration --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He doesn't -- he just doesn't say, I'm going to give you 15 years without regard to the credit then leave it up to the prison authorities to say --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: It's done both ways, he can --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is it done both ways?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, he can say that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I want to give you 15 years and the prison authorities will credit you in the time, all that he served.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Will credit you for time served, yes or he can compute it himself as he --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And here, he did it the other way?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And is it clear that he did it the other way?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I -- it's clear to me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the prison authorities would not give him credit for any more time on his eight-year sentence?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: No, they gave him credit --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think the judge has already given him all the credit he deserves?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, yes.
He gave him -- he specifically stated in giving him --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So he will be in no position to claim any more credit from the prison authorities on account of the sentence that he'd already served?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct because at the time the second sentencing judge imposed sentence he had before him --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At least that seems to be the basis on which this case comes here?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
He had before him the prison records which showed exactly how much gain and flat time this defendant had served on the first sentence.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because if he were still entitled to credit on the eight-year sentence for all the time that he had served before, there wouldn't be much left, would there?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: No, that's true.

If we compute it from the maximum that would be allowable under the statute, he still has approximately almost six years to serve under -- even by way of the Patton Court's reasoning, he would have an additional time to serve.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: And I believe that Judge Butler points that out in his order ordering the state to resentence him or to release him and of course the state when it came on for hearing before the state judge, the judge refused to order this man resentence and Judge Butler thereupon entered an order requiring his immediate release and that is why we appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals which in a memorandum decision based upon Patton versus North Carolina affirmed the District Court's holding.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Vanore, this second trial was held before the same judge as who would -- as had presided the first trial or not?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I don't believe so, no.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And didn't make any difference?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that the argument might be greater if it were held before the same trial judge as was done in the Sanders case from California that the second trial judge might have more reason perhaps if we want to assume that the trial judge is going to be vindictive, that the second judge might have more reason for imposing a harsher sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in both cases, both the first trial and the second trial in this case is what I mean, the sentence was imposed by the judge not by the jury?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: It is imposed by the judge in North Carolina by statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And he is -- the jury's function is only to find guilt or innocence?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the jury nor your state has no function with respect to fixing the severity of the sentence, is that right?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Except in a capital case, the jury can return a verdict of guilty without leniency and thereupon the defendant is sentenced to death.
However, they can impose leniency and the statute provides automatically for a life imprisonment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But in this kind of a case, in this case (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, this kind of a case, the judge has the complete unfettered discretion to impose any sentence which he deems necessary under the facts.
The only prohibition that is put upon the second sentencing judge is that the time served under the first sentence which was voided --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Has to be credited?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Has to be credited and the time served under the first sentence and the time imposed under the second sentence --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Cannot exceed the maximum, alright.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: -- cannot exceed that maximum allowed by the statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The statutory maximum.

Now, you have already alluded to your position which perhaps you'll amplify a little further because it's emphasized in your brief that it's improper to assume that a judge or a -- whether it be the same judge or another judge in the same court after a second trial would be vindictive and would be motivated to penalize the person for having appealed his first conviction.
I understand that position.
What would you say if there were proof that the second sentencing judge had been in fact vindictive?

What if he had been frank enough to say, well you appealed your first conviction and we don't -- I don't think that was proper -- you what -- put the state to a great deal of expense and trouble and now the juries found you guilty all over again.
And since you did appeal your first conviction I'm hereby going to sentence you to twice as long of sentence within the statutory maximum.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: That would be a flagrant violation of the man's constitutional right to appeal --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of what constitutional right?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: The constitutional right to appeal without any fear of reprisal.
And our Supreme Court so held in a case called State versus Patton --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: -- where the sentencing judge -- yes, first imposed the fine on the individual.
And then the individual gave notice of appeal and the sentencing judge thereupon struck his first sentence of a fine and imposed active time.
Our Supreme Court said that this was a flagrant violation of the man's constitutional right to appeal without fear of any reprisal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now how often do you think that the -- that you could educe evidence that the motivation of the second sentencing judge was a vindictive motivation of that type?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would be extremely difficult to educe that type of evidence but I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Normally a judge would simply --

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: I think that we have -- yes.
I think that we have to presume though since -- as I see it, our whole system is based upon the good faith of judges.

We have to assume that the sentencing judge is not going to be vindictive and if he were vindictive, he could easily circumvent the rule that was applied in Patton by imposing the maximum sentence the first time around and then there would never be any question about it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did your court hold that that sentence would be void unconstitutional under the state constitution or under the federal?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Under the state and federal constitution.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the Patton case?

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr
turn.label: Mr. Andrew A. Vanore, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: andrew_a_vanore_jr

turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is fair in North Carolina.

This is what we're going to require but what -- my question I think you understand it is, what if a state doesn't have that rule, if a man is sentenced to five years in the penitentiary though in the first conviction he gets a reversal after serving two years time.
He's tried again convicted by a jury; the judge sentences him to five years in the penitentiary.
You say that's not permissible either, is that right?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
I think even if the state didn't have the rule as North Carolina does that it would still be unconstitutional and impermissible.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What would you say about giving the first trial to get a fair distinction (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: This case, I don't think I would go that far.
It's not in this case, of course, Your Honor.
But I don't think the restraint placed on a person while he is on bail is the restraint that is placed on him while he is on custody.
And I don't think the rule would go that far.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, suppose he's not out on bail, he is in jail, he waits two years to be tried, does the Constitution require to get a fair trial?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: I think by natural extension, it could, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: In answer to Justice Black, you said this was a one of the requirements of a fair trial.
I thought this was a double jeopardy case, isn't it?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: We do raise that issue too, Your Honor, that it violates double jeopardy because it is in effect a multiple punishment.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Have we ever held that the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment is applicable to the states by reason of the Fourteenth?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: No sir, you have not.
And I state in my brief that the way I understand it you have this issue before you in a case, Benton versus Maryland.
And I think it's -- it has been argued once and is set for re-argument squarely presented in that case.
But in this -- in Patton, when faced with this rule, the Fourth Circuit relied on the (Inaudible) case and stated that it was applicable to the states.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What case -- I was -- my question to you Mr. Sitton is going to be that even assuming -- even assuming, let's assume that the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Bill of Rights is fully applicable to the states, is there any federal case, is there any federal that says that the sentencing of a person on a second trial after he's won a new trial to a greater sentence violates the Double Jeopardy Clause?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: No sir, there is not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think there was.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's a case that say it isn't though.

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In this trial?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: Well, I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In this Court?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: I think -- I think that those cases if we make reference to Stroud and the Murphy versus Massachusetts that was the factual reality that there was an increased sentence in both cases but I don't think that the Court face that issue.
I think in both of those cases that the argument was made -- that the second trial itself was barred --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But we have held --

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: --by the Double Jeopardy Clause.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: We have held that if the man on the first trial against life and on the second trial after an appeal gets death, that's double jeopardy.

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: I think that was the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: It was a federal case.

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: -- the fact in Stroud and in Stroud that was (Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: That was a Green case, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: I think in Green, he was convicted of first degree -- he was acquitted a first degree murder, convicted of second degree murder and then a subsequent trial was convicted of first degree murder and this Court said that the conviction of second degree murder at the first trial was an implied acquittal of first degree murder and that's the basis we say that --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I thought that -- those are the semantics the judges sometime use but --

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: I think it was observed that there can be no distinction between the Stroud case and the Green case, that there is no difference --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Stroud, you say only turn really on the old law that, perhaps still law, that a second trial after a successful appeal is not in and out of itself a violation of double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
I think that was a sole issue that was brought forward.
The constitutional arguments that were made in this case were not made in Stroud.
They were made in Green to some extent and in Green it was held that person was impliedly acquitted.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if your argument had been made in Stroud, do you suppose that Stroud would have been more -- anymore successful than in Green?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: Maybe not at that time, I hope he would --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That -- at that time, clearly double jeopardy -- there's no suggestion of double jeopardy by the state, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Wasn't that Kansas?

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: Stroud?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I think it's a -- there was a federal (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: larry_b_sitton
turn.label: Mr. Larry B. Sitton
turn.text: If the court have any further questions?
Thank you.
